title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #754: Favorite Distances in ℝ⁴**

For n points in ℝ⁴, what's the maximum k such that EVERY point has at least k equidistant neighbors?

**Question:** Is f(n) ≤ n/2 + O(1)?

**Answer: YES** - Swanepoel (2013)

Swanepoel's stronger result: Σ 1_{|x-y|=d(x)} ≤ (1/2)n² + O(n) for any distance assignment d(x).
mathContext: Avis-Erdős-Pach (1988) gave initial bounds; Swanepoel (2013) completed the solution.

title: Point Configuration
content:
**PointConfig d n:**

A configuration of n points in d-dimensional Euclidean space: Fin n → EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin d).

This represents any arrangement of n labeled points in ℝᵈ.

title: Equidistant Set
content:
**equidistantSet A x r:**

The set of points y ≠ x with |A(x) - A(y)| = r.

This captures 'all points at distance r from x' in the configuration.

title: Favorite Count
content:
**favoriteCount A x:**

The maximum over all distances r of |equidistantSet A x r|.

This is the largest number of points equidistant from x at any single distance - the 'favorite distance' achieves this count.

title: The Function f(n)
content:
**f d n:**

The maximum over all n-point configurations A in ℝᵈ of (minimum over x of favoriteCount A x).

In words: f(n) is the largest k such that some configuration has EVERY point with at least k equidistant neighbors.

title: Avis-Erdős-Pach Lower Bound
content:
**avis_erdos_pach_lower_bound:**

f(n) ≥ n/2 + 2 for n ≥ 4 in ℝ⁴.

**Construction:** Use the Clifford torus - place n/2 points on each of two orthogonal circles. Points on different circles are all equidistant!
mathContext: From 'Repeated distances in space', Graphs Combin. (1988).

title: Distance Assignment
content:
**DistanceAssignment n:**

A function Fin n → ℝ assigning a 'favorite distance' d(x) to each point x.

Swanepoel's result is stronger because it applies to ANY such assignment, not just the optimal one.

title: Swanepoel's Main Theorem
content:
**swanepoel_2013:**

For any configuration A and distance assignment d:

Σ_{x,y} 1_{|x-y|=d(x)} ≤ (1/2)n² + O(n)

The total count of 'favorite distance pairs' is at most quadratic with leading coefficient 1/2.

title: Swanepoel Solves Erdős 754
content:
**swanepoel_erdos_754:**

f(n) ≤ n/2 + O(1) for ℝ⁴.

This answers Erdős's question affirmatively. Combined with the lower bound, we get f(n) = n/2 + Θ(1).

title: Problem Solved
content:
**erdos_754_solved:**

Combines the bounds: ∃ C₁ C₂, n/2 + C₁ ≤ f(n) ≤ n/2 + C₂.

**Proof:** Uses avis_erdos_pach_lower_bound (C₁ = 2) and swanepoel_erdos_754 (get C₂).

The answer is f(n) = n/2 + Θ(1) - determined up to an additive constant.

title: Clifford Torus Construction
content:
**cliffordTorusConstruction:**

The Clifford torus is S¹ × S¹ ⊂ ℝ⁴. Key property: points on two orthogonal circles have constant pairwise distance.

**Construction:** Take n/2 points on each circle. Each point has n/2 equidistant neighbors (those on the other circle). This achieves f(n) ≥ n/2.

title: Summary Theorem
content:
**erdos_754_summary:**

Two parts:
1. Lower bound: ∀ n ≥ 4, f(n) ≥ n/2 + 2
2. Upper bound: ∀ n ≥ 4, ∃ C, f(n) ≤ n/2 + C

The function f(n) for 'favorite distances' in ℝ⁴ grows exactly as n/2 + O(1).
